sen.e: He was called Nochi-no-Sambo (latter three "Fusa(房))" retainers, Chikafusa KITABATAKE (北畠親房), Nobufusa MADENOKOJI (万里小路宣房) and Sadafusa YOSHIDA (吉田定房)) together with Sadafusa YOSHIDA and Nobufusa MADENOKOJI, and was enjoying a deep confidence of Emperor Godaigo.

He was called Nochi-no-Sambo (literally, 'the latter three "Fusa(房)" retainer'), Chikafusa KITABATAKE (北畠親房), Nobufusa MADENOKOJI (万里小路宣房) and Sadafusa YOSHIDA (吉田定房)) together with Sadafusa YOSHIDA and Nobufusa MADENOKOJI, and enjoyed the deep confidence of Emperor Godaigo.

sen.j: これまで北畠氏には許されていなかった源氏長者（1323年（元亨3年））・大納言（1325年（正中 (日本)元年））に任命されるが、1330年（元徳2年）、世良親王急死の責任を感じて38歳の若さで出家（当時、従二位大納言・源氏長者・内教坊別当）して政界から一旦は引退している（この時、従一位と儀同三司（准大臣）に任じられた（時期については異説あり）。
sen.e: He was appointed as a leader of Genji (in 1323) and as a chief councilor of state (in 1325), any of which had been disallowed for the Kitabatake clan so far, but at the age of 38 in 1330, he became a priest (at that time, Junii rank, Dainagon (chief councilor of state), a leader of Genji and Naikyobo no Betto (chief of Naikyobo,)) feeling responsible for the sudden death of Imperial Prince Yoyoshi to resign from politics once (at that time, Juichii rank and Gido-sanshi minister (vice minister)) (there is heresy regarding the periods.)

At the age of 38 in 1330, he became a priest (at that time, Junii rank, Dainagon (chief councillor of state), a leader of Genji and Naikyobo no Betto (chief of Naikyobo,)), and feeling responsible for the sudden death of Imperial Prince Yoyoshi he resigned from politics immediately (at that time, Juichii rank and Gido-sanshi minister (vice minister)) (there were conflicting reports regarding the periods).

sen.j: 従って、正中の変にはじまる後醍醐の鎌倉幕府倒幕計画には加担してはいなかったようである（その一方で父・師重の従兄弟にあたる北畠具行が元弘の変で処刑されている）。
sen.e: Because of that, he didn't seem to be involved in the Emperor Godaigo's plan to overthrow the Kamakura Bakufu, which was started with the Shochu no Hen (Conspiracy of Shochu) (however, Tomoyuki KITABATAKE, a cousin of his father Morishige was put to death in the Genko no Hen (Conspiracy of Genko.))

Because of that, he didn't seem to be involved in the Emperor Godaigo's plan to overthrow the Kamakura Bakufu, which was started with the Shochu no Hen (Conspiracy of Shochu) (however, Tomoyuki KITABATAKE, a cousin of his father Morishige was put to death in the Genko no Hen (Conspiracy of Genko)).

Because of that, he didn't seem to be involved in the Emperor Godaigo's plan to overthrow the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which was started with the Shochu no Hen (Conspiracy of Shochu) (however, Tomoyuki KITABATAKE, a cousin of his father Moroshige was put to death in the Genko no Hen (Conspiracy of Genko)).

sen.j: 奥州鎮定を命じられた息子北畠顕家に随行し、義良親王（後の後村上天皇）を奉じて陸奥国多賀城へ赴く。
sen.e: He accompanied his son Akiie KITABATAKE, who was directed to execute the suppression of Oshu and departed for Mutsu-no-kuni Tagajo in obedience to Imperial Prince Norinaga's order (later, Emperor Gomurakami.)

sen.j: 1335年（建武 (日本)2年）、北条氏の残党による中先代の乱が起き、討伐に向かった足利尊氏がそのまま建武政権から離反すると、尊氏を討伐するために京へ戻り、尊氏に京都を占領されると、京都を逃れた後醍醐が吉野（奈良県吉野郡吉野町）で開いた吉野朝廷に従い、北朝 (日本)と対抗する。
sen.e: In 1335 when Takauji ASHIKAGA went to put down the Nakasendai-no-ran War set off by the Hojo clan's remnants and directly seceded from the Kemmu Government, Chikafusa returned to Kyoto to subdue Takauji, and since Emperor Godaigo ran away from Kyoto captured by Takauji and established the Yoshino Imperial in Yoshino (Yoshino Town, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture), he opposed against the Hokucho dynasty (Japan) supporting the Yoshino Imperial.

In 1335, when Takauji ASHIKAGA went to put down the Nakasendai-no-ran War set off by the Hojo clan's remnants, and he directly seceded from the Kemmu Government, Chikafusa returned to Kyoto to subdue him. Chikafusa opposed the support given by the Hokucho dynasty (Japan) to the Yoshino Imperial Court, established by Takauji in Yoshino (Yoshino Town, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture) after capturing Kyoto and forcing the flight of Emperor Godaigo.
sen.cmt: This is the best I can do with this one. There may be other ways to tweak it to sound more natural.
sen.e: In 1335, when Takauji ASHIKAGA went to put down the Nakasendai War set off by the Hojo clan's remnants and eventually seceded from the Kenmu Government, Chikafusa returned to Kyoto to subdue him; after Takauji captured Kyoto, Chikafusa confronted the Northern Court, followingYoshino Imperial Court which was established in Yoshino (Yoshino Town, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture) by Emperor Godaigo, who had to leave Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に沿うよう、書き換えました。

sen.j: 1338年（延元3年/暦応元年）に息子顕家が戦死した後、親房は伊勢国において、度会家行の協力を得て南朝勢力の拡大を図る。
sen.e: After his son Akiie died in a war in 1338, Chikafusa endeavored to strengthen the Nancho power in Ise-no-kuni in cooperation with Ieyuki WATARAI.
After his son Akiie died in a war in 1338, Chikafusa cooperated with Ieyuki WATARAI to strengthen Nancho power in Ise-no-kuni.

sen.e: Chikafusa, thereby, was deeply influenced by Ieyuki's Shinkoku-shiso (thought of Japan as the land of the gods) (however, he seemed to be critical of the Ise-Shinto religion itself advocated by Ieyuki.)

sen.j: その後、関東地方に南朝勢力を拡大するために結城宗広とともに、義良親王・宗良親王を奉じて伊勢国大湊（三重県伊勢市）から海路東国へ渡ろうとするが、暴風にあい両親王とは離散し単独で常陸国へ上陸。
sen.e: Later, to strengthen the Nancho power in the Kanto Region, he attempted to reach the Togoku (the eastern part of Japan ranging as far east as Kinki, such as Kanto Region) by sea from Ise-no-kuni Ominato (Ise City, Mie Prefecture) with Munehiro YUKI in obedience to Imperial Prince Norinaga's and Imperial Prince Muneyoshi's orders, but he separated from the both Princes due to heavy storms and arrived in the Hitachi-no-kuni alone.

Later, in accordance with Imperial Prince Norinaga's order to strengthen Nancho power in the Kanto Region, he attempted to reach the Togoku (the eastern part of Japan ranging as far east as Kinki, such as the Kanto Region) by sea from Ise-no-kuni Ominato (Ise City, Mie Prefecture) with Munehiro YUKI. However, he separated from both of the Princes due to heavy storms and arrived in the Hitachi-no-kuni alone.

Later, in accordance with the order of Imperial Princes Norinaga and Munenaga to strengthen the power of the Southern Court in the Kanto Region, he attempted to reach the Togoku (the eastern part of Japan) by sea from Ominato in Ise Province (Ise City, Mie Prefecture) with Munehiro YUKI. However, he separated from both of the Princes due to heavy storms and arrived in Hitachi Province alone.

sen.j: 1340年（興国元年/暦応3年）、北朝方が高師冬を関東統治のために派遣すると、小田氏に見限られた親房は関宗祐の関城（茨城県筑西市）に入り、大宝城（茨城県下妻市）の下妻氏、伊佐城（茨城県筑西市）の伊佐氏 (常陸国)など常陸西部の南朝勢力とともに対抗する。
sen.e: In 1340 when the Hokucho dynasty side sent KO no Morofuyu to govern the Kanto, Chikafusa who was given up by the Oda clan entered Munesuke SEKI's Seki Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture) to fight against them together with the Nancho dynasty's forces including the Shimotsuma clan in Daiho Castle (Shimotsuma City, Ibaraki Prefecture) and the Isa clan (Hitachi-no-kuni) in Isa Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture).

In 1340 when the Hokucho dynasty side sent KO no Morofuyu to govern Kanto, Chikafusa, who was abandoned by the Oda clan, entered Munesuke SEKI's Seki Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture) to fight against them together with the Nancho dynasty's forces including the Shimotsuma clan in Daiho Castle (Shimotsuma City, Ibaraki Prefecture) and the Isa clan (Hitachi-no-kuni) in Isa Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture).

In 1340 when the Northern Court side sent KO no Morofuyu to govern Kanto region, Chikafusa, who was abandoned by the Oda clan, entered Munesuke SEKI's Seki Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture) to fight against them together with the Southern Court's forces including the Shimotsuma clan in Daiho Castle (Shimotsuma City, Ibaraki Prefecture) and the Isa clan (Hitachi Province) in Isa Castle (Chikusei City, Ibaraki Prefecture).

sen.j: しかし、南朝方に従った近衛経忠（南朝の関白左大臣）が藤氏長者の立場で独自に東国の藤原氏系武士団の統率体制を組もうとした。
sen.e: However, there also happened an incident that Tsunetada KONOE (Sadaijin (minister of the left of Dajokan) as a chief adviser to the Emperor in the Nancho dynasty) who was supporting the Nancho dynasty independently attempted to make a network of leading the Warriors of Fujiwara clan group in the Togoku in the position of the leader of Toshi/Toji, and after Chikafusa's plots got to be undermined by both pros and cons and the both castles were destroyed in 1343, he returned to Yoshino.

Chikafusa returned to Yoshino after his plots were undermined by both the inside and outside and both castles were destroyed in 1343.

However, Tsunetada KONOE (Sadaijin (minister of the left of Dajokan) as a chief adviser to the Emperor in the Southern Court), who was supporting the Southern Court independently, attempted to lead a network of Warriors of Fujiwara clan group in the Togoku (the eastern part of Japan) using the status of the leader of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.e: As the Nancho dynasty side including Masatsura KUSUNOKI lost the Battle of Shijonawate against KO no Moronao in 1348, he escaped from Yoshino to Ano (Gojo City, Nara Prefecture.)
When the Nancho dynasty side, including Masatsura KUSUNOKI, lost the Battle of Shijonawate against KO no Moronao in 1348, he escaped from Yoshino to Ano (Gojo City, Nara Prefecture.)

sen.j: 後醍醐の死後は後村上天皇を補佐した。
